title: 106_hr816
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments are included in income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" mandates that unpaid child support payments are treated as taxable income. This includes applicable child support payments required under a support instrument for the taxpayer's child. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" requires taxpayers to pay child support under a support instrument, and if payments are not made, the taxpayer must notify the individual who failed to make payments to include the amount in their gross income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" mandates taxpayers to make support payments, with notification required if payments are not made to include the amount in gross income. If the address is unknown, the Secretary will send notice if available, and no income will be included if no address is known. Subsequent payments made must be included in gross income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" requires taxpayers to make support payments, with notification needed if payments are not made to include the amount in gross income. Subsequent payments made must be included in gross income. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers, with a limit of $10,000 per child. Eligible taxpayers are individuals with a certain adjusted gross income. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments up to $10,000 per child. Eligible taxpayers must have an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000 and unpaid child support payments of $500 or more at the end of the taxable year. The term 'support payment' refers to periodic payments required by an individual under a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child. A qualifying child is defined as a child for whom a deduction is allowable under specific tax code sections. Payments must be delinquent for at least an entire year. An eligible individual with a deductible payment under section 151 for the taxable year must have delinquent payments for at least a year. Coordination with TANF excludes certain amounts from being considered as applicable child support payments. The identification requirements for claiming a deduction under this subsection include providing the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of each child and the individual required to make child support payments. Failure to provide this information may result in the deduction not applying. In the case of a failure to provide required information for claiming a deduction, the deduction may not apply. Cost-of-living adjustments increase certain dollar amounts for taxable years after 2000. The tax code allows for deductions under specific circumstances, including subsequent payments and support instruments like divorce decrees or separation agreements. The tax code allows deductions for unpaid child support payments, including those outlined in divorce decrees, separation agreements, or court orders for child support. These deductions apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will be used solely to pay off the US public debt, as specified in appropriation Acts, and cannot be used for any other purpose.
